dt: {bc}to send out of the country by legal {a_link|deportation}
{bc}to behave or comport (oneself) especially in accord with a code

pt: {sc}banish{/sc} {sc}exile{/sc} {sc}deport{/sc} {sc}transport{/sc} mean to remove by authority from a state or country. {sc}banish{/sc} implies compulsory removal from a country not necessarily one's own.
{sc}exile{/sc} may imply compulsory removal or an enforced or voluntary absence from one's own country.

pt.t: a writer who {it}exiled{/it} himself for political reasons

pt: {sc}deport{/sc} implies sending out of the country an alien who has illegally entered or whose presence is judged inimical to the public welfare.
{sc}transport{/sc} implies sending a convicted criminal to an overseas penal colony.

pt.t: a convict who was {it}transported{/it} to Australia

pt: {sc}behave{/sc} {sc}conduct{/sc} {sc}deport{/sc} {sc}comport{/sc} {sc}acquit{/sc} mean to act or to cause oneself to do something in a certain way. {sc}behave{/sc} may apply to the meeting of a standard of what is proper or decorous.
{sc}conduct{/sc} implies action or behavior that shows the extent of one's power to control or direct oneself.
{sc}deport{/sc} implies behaving so as to show how far one conforms to conventional rules of discipline or propriety.

pt.t: the hero {it}deported{/it} himself in accord with the code of chivalry

pt: {sc}comport{/sc} suggests conduct measured by what is expected or required of one in a certain class or position.
{sc}acquit{/sc} applies to action under stress that deserves praise or meets expectations.

pt.t: {it}acquitted{/it} herself well in her first assignment

et: Middle French {it}deporter{/it}, from Latin {it}deportare{/it} to carry away, from {it}de-{/it} + {it}portare{/it} to carry {ma}{mat|fare|}{/ma}
shortdef: to send out of the country by legal deportation
to behave or comport (oneself) especially in accord with a code
